column1: Approximately half this number will see their monthly bills go down

column1: For the record: An earlier version of this column incorrectly stated that Edison customers cannot change back to their previous rate plan after the first year. They can make once-a-year changes.
And roughly 100
column2: 000 Edison customers could see their electricity bills climb by hundreds of dollars a year unless they opt out or significantly change their behavior.

column1: Californians are now facing one of the most sweeping changes to how they pay for energy. Ensuring ratepayers are well-informed about the stakes — and the decisions they have to make — is crucial. Edison could be doing a better job.
A spokesperson for the utility challenged that characterization. We’ll get back to that.

I learned about the Edison rate change from a Palm Springs resident named Lynn Pettit
column2: who sent me a copy of the letter she received from the utility informing her about the transition
column3: which in her case takes effect in December.

column1: “Is it a scam?” she asked.
“I thought at first that the letter seemed reasonable
column2: ” Pettit
column4: told me. “Then I read the rest of it and I thought
column5: ‘What?'""

column1: OK
column2: this next bit is a little wonky
column3: so hang in there.

column1: It won’t come as a news flash to anyone that California’s power grid is straining to keep up with demand as climate change affects electricity usage
column2: especially during increasingly sizzling summers.

column1: Crazy-hot temps mean millions of air conditioners running simultaneously. Blackouts are a perennial possibility.
To help fix this
column2: the California Public Utilities Commission ordered Edison
column3: Pacific Gas & Electric and San Diego Gas & Electric to switch most customers to so-called time-of-use rate plans.

column1: The idea is to offer lower rates to people during off-peak hours. Basically
column2: demand is highest between 4 p.m. and 9 p.m.
column3: when solar power is less plentiful and energy can cost about 60% more on summer weekdays.

column1: Time-of-use plans allow most ratepayers to save money if they concentrate their energy use — running the washing machine
column2: say — outside that time frame.

column1: Edison has already moved about a million residential customers and most business customers to time-of-use plans. It’s now notifying 2.3 million more residential customers that it’s their turn
column2: with rate changes occurring in waves from November to next April.

column1: Let’s stipulate right here that time-of-use rate plans are a good idea. They incentivize consumers to ease the burden on the power grid
column2: make more use of alternative energy sources and generally be nicer to Mother Nature.

column1: But if the letter received by Pettit is any indication
column2: Edison could be doing a better job selling the concept.

column1: “Time-of-use plans encourage people to use energy at the times of day when renewable energy
column2: like solar and wind
column3: is the most abundant and at the lowest cost
column4: ” it says.

column1: “With small changes in your energy habits
column2: you can save money and help our state meet its clean energy goals.”

column1: Then comes the first curve ball. The letter says Pettit and other Edison customers will be moved automatically to time-of-use plans unless they opt out.
Let’s be real clear about this: Opt-outs are almost always a red flag for consumers. They typically signal that something is good for companies but bad for customers.
The sharing of your personal information
column2: for instance. If you don’t want a company doing that
column3: you have to opt out (and even then
column4: businesses will still do it on a limited basis).

column1: Companies are well aware that relatively few consumers will make the effort to opt out of things
column2: which is why important decisions are routinely presented as opt-outs rather than opt-ins. Call it corporate coercion.

column1: By the same token
column2: though
column3: many if not most consumers won’t opt in to things that they didn’t initiate. They’ll ignore the offer.

column1: This is a Catch-22 of modern life. Opt-outs are often unfair. Opt-ins are frequently ineffective.
Edison’s letter to Pettit makes clear that the change to her rate plan is not in her favor. It states that
column2: under her current plan
column3: she pays about $4
column4: 467 a year for power.

column1: Under the pending time-of-use plan
column2: it says
column3: she’ll pay $4
column4: 705 a year — a more than 5% rate hike.

column1: The letter says that for the first 12 months after the switch
column2: she’ll receive a one-time credit from Edison if her time-of-use bills exceed her current payments. It says she can switch back to her current plan during the first year. Once-a-year changes are also possible after this time.

column1: “I wonder how many people won’t read the letter
column2: or won’t check their bills on a regular basis
column3: ” Pettit told me. “The only reasonable way to do this is to ask people to opt in.”

column1: Normally I’d agree with that. But in this case
column2: the stakes are exceedingly high
column3: and it’s crucial that as many Californians as possible participate in the new rate plan.

column1: Ron Gales
column2: an Edison spokesperson
column3: said the Southern California utility and Northern California’s PG&E originally favored the idea of opt-ins when statewide plans for the switch to time-of-use rates started taking shape about a decade ago.

column1: California regulators
column2: however
column3: saw that Sacramento’s community-owned utility had better luck with opt-outs
column4: so the edict was handed down: Opt-outs for all.

column1: From Edison’s perspective
column2: this was the right move.

column1: Gales told me that when the utility tested opt-ins with some customers
column2: only about 5% agreed to switch to the new plan. That’s 95% who either didn’t want to change or couldn’t be bothered to even think about it.

column1: “We’re trying to alter the behavior of millions of people
column2: ” Gales observed. “How do you do that if hardly anyone opts in?”

column1: San Diego’s utility finished moving eligible residential customers to time-of-use rates in May 2020. According to the PUC
column2: 98% of the total remained on the new plan.

column1: Gales said most Edison customers will see lower bills as a result of moving to time-of-use plans and making modest changes to their energy use.
But he acknowledged that for about 100
column2: 000 “extreme non-benefitters” such as Pettit
column3: average monthly bills could rise by as much as 10% from current levels.

column1: “We recognize that
column2: ” he told me. “We’ll be following up with such people by phone.”

column1: I pointed out that amid a proliferation of scam calls
column2: many people no longer pick up the phone. “That’s a valid point
column3: ” Gales acknowledged — another quirk of modern life.

column1: Where Edison dropped the ball
column2: I think
column3: is in making the case to the tens of thousands of people like Pettit who will look at their letters and conclude they’re being hit with a hefty rate increase.

column1: Gales explained that the estimates for current payments versus time-of-use payments don’t factor in behavioral changes a customer might make.
That is
column2: Pettit and others could still see their bills go down if they adjust their energy use to avoid peak hours.

column1: Edison could have done a better job communicating this.
What it should have done is provide not two but three data points — estimated current bills
column2: estimated time-of-use bills and estimated time-of-use bills with new behavior factored in.

column1: Gales said Edison’s honchos considered estimating for people like Pettit how much their bills could decline if they adapted to time-of-use conditions. “We just didn’t have a lot of confidence in our numbers
column2: ” he conceded.

column1: I said earlier this was wonky. Now you see why.
The bottom line for all Californians is that the changeover to time-of-use rates is a good thing and should help us better manage our energy resources
column2: especially on hot summer days.
